contentrichtext.text: {{About|||Georgy Porgy (disambiguation){{!}}Georgy Porgy}} {{Infobox Standard <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Songs --> | title = Georgie Porgie | english_title = | comment = [[Roud]] #19532 | image = | image_size = | caption = | writer = Traditional | composer = | lyricist = | published = 1840s | written = England | language = [[English language|English]] | form = [[Nursery rhyme]] | original_artist = | recorded_by = | performed_by = }} '''"Georgie Porgie"''' is a popular [[English language]] [[nursery rhyme]]. It has a [[Roud Folk Song Index]] number of 19532. ==Lyrics== The most common modern lyrics are: :Georgie Porgie, Puddin' and Pie, :Kissed the girls and made them cry, :When the boys came out to play :Georgie Porgie ran away.<ref name=Opie1997>I. Opie and P. Opie, ''The Oxford Dictionary of Nursery Rhymes'' (Oxford University Press, 1951, 2nd edn., 1997), pp. 185-6.</ref> ==Origins and meaning== The first recorded version of the rhyme was collected by [[James Orchard Halliwell]] in the mid-19th century with the lyrics: :Rowley Powley, pumpkin pie, :Kissed the girls and made them cry; :When the girls began to cry, :Rowly Powley runs away.<ref name=Opie1997/> However, the version with Georgie Porgie was known to [[George Bernard Shaw]] (1856-1950) in his childhood and so may be at least as old. There are various theories that link the character Georgie Porgie to historical figures including [[George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham]] (1592-1628), [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] (1630-1685) and [[George I of England|George I]] (1660-1727), but there is no evidence to corroborate such claims.<ref name=Opie1997/> ==Cultural references== ''[[Kiss the Girls and Make Them Die]]'' is the [[United States|US]] title of the 1966 [[James Bond]] parody ''[[Se Tutte le Donne del Mondo]]''.<ref>IMDb, Kiss the Girls and Make Them Die (1966), http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0060592/, retrieved 17/02/11.</ref> ''[[Kiss the Girls]]'' is the title of a 1995 [[James Patterson]] detective novel, adapted as a film with [[Morgan Freeman]] in the major role in 1997.<ref>IMDb, Kiss the girls (1997), http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119468/, retrieved 12/04/09.</ref> In music the rock group [[Toto (band)|Toto]] recorded a song called "[[Georgy Porgy (song)|Georgy Porgy]]" on its 1978 [[Toto (album)|debut album]] that includes lines from the nursery rhyme. The song was written by Toto keyboard player [[David Paich]].<ref>[http://www.post-lyrics.com/5-TOTO-PAST_TO_PRESENT_HITS.html].</ref> The first line is sang by Supercat near the end of [[Sugar Ray]]'s song 'Fly'. A reference to the rhyme is made in [[Aldous Huxley]]'s '[[Brave New World]]'' (1932), Chapter five: :Orgy-porgy, Ford and fun, :Kiss the girls and make them One. :Boys at one with girls at peace; :Orgy-porgy gives release. ==Notes== {{reflist}} [[Category:Nursery rhymes]] [[Category:1840s songs]] {{poetry-stub}}
